title: Window
body:
Have you ever had something happen, that's completely changed your view of reality? Yeah, probably not. You've probably been drifting along your entire life, completely unaware of what goes on outside of your very small plane of existence. No offense, of course.

Well, unlike you, my life just changed for ever. Now, I've never been a believer in the paranormal; I've never believed in monsters, and I sure as hell don't believe in ghosts. Now though, I can tell you that I still don't. I don't know what that thing was last night, but it definitely wasn't a ghost, and I don't think it was paranormal. No, it was something different.

Anyway, on with my story. Last night, I was trying to go to sleep, and as always, thanks to my infernal insomnia, I couldn't. I tossed and turned, I removed covers, and five minutes later, I piled them back on. I even got up and drank a glass of warm milk, but that did nothing. I stared out of my window for a solid five minutes, watching the trees. I got out of bed and opened it, but sadly, no breeze was blowing. I closed it not long after.

I couldn't find my cat, so I walked down my stairs, opened my door, and walked out. He was one of those inside-outside cats, always running in and out. Okay, this is completely off topic, but his name is Clovis, after that one French guy. First king of the Franks or something, I don't really know. I just liked the name.

This is where it starts to get weird. As I was walking, I got this feeling. It wasn't the feeling of being watched, but it was close. It was more the feeling of being, I don't know, noticed? Have you ever felt that? It was weird as hell. It was almost comforting, really. It felt vaugely like a mother's watchful gaze, the kind that she'd give you back when you were young and playing near a road. Cautious, but loving.

Actually, it didn't feel like that at all. It felt like it wanted me to feel that way. It felt like the illusion of love. The closest thing I can use to describe it is an angler fish. They use their light to make you feel safe, and then murders you, with no remorse. Yeah, it was like that.

Thankfully, I didn't pay it much attention at the time. I've never been very observant. Not long after, l spotted my cat. He was always really easy to find. Clumsy, you know? I'd be searching for him, and he'd fall out of a tree right by me. He was also easy to spot because of his color scheme; he was orange and white, so he stuck out like a thumb that was leaking pus. Or one that has herpes, I can't really remember that simile.

Back on topic, I picked up my cat, and headed to my house. He really hadn't gone that far, so I had returned before long. I opened the door, and as soon as I did, he scratched me and jumped out of my hands. He never was very friendly, but I loved him nonetheless.

I knew I wasn't going to get any sleep that night, so I grabbed a Soda and sat down on my couch. I turned on the tv, and took a healthy drink. They say that stuff isn't good for you, but oh well. I'm gonna die someday, right?

As I was sitting there, I got that feeling again. I sat there, experiencing it for a good while, wondering what was causing it. I was zapped back into reality by a banging from upstairs. I assumed it was just my cat, until I saw him walk in from my kitchen, meowing. I started to get a little creeped out.

Now, I'll admit I did the stupid thing. I should've ran outside and called the police, but instead, I grabbed my cat and ran upstairs. Now, I know what you're thinking. "You stupid bastard! You're supposed to run AWAY from the danger, not towards it!" Well, all I have to say to that is, "Uh yeah. You're completely right."

Ignoring my obvious stupidity, and moving on with my story, I got upstairs, and saw nothing. Everything was exactly as I left it; my bed looked exactly the same, and my window was still open.

I'll admit it took me longer than it should've to notice what was wrong. My window was open. The first thing to go through my head was, "Well, I'm fucking dead." I'm fairly certain I even said that out loud.

It was at this point, that I finally did the smart thing, albeit much too late. I booked it down the stairs. I didn't make it too far, probably the second step from the top, when I felt whatever it was tear through me. It was sharp, and it stabbed straight through my back.

I know, I'm leaving a very important question unanswered. If I'm dead, then how am I writing this? Well, if you really want to know, I'm right outside your window. All you have to do is open up and ask.
author: CigoNoka
